text: Being passionate about what we do
is one of the reasons why we
are here, and it allows individuals
like myself who've been doing this
for decades to be very excited
about what I do and to continue
to give me the passion to come
in every day and make a difference.
South wire is a manufacturing
company. We make electrical wire,
wire that crisscrosses the United
States. And wire that's in your
homes, as well as in the buildings
that we're in.
Founded by a graduate of
Georgia Tech who decided that what
he wanted to do was to bring
electricity to his grandmother
in rural Georgia.
So our story is really about
what we can do to help others, and
what we can do to help the electric
grid, as well as the infrastructure
for bringing in electricity around
the U.S..
We make the wire that goes from
the wall all the way back to the
generation site at the utility
companies, but it's also what
we do to help infrastructure
so that it can prepare for all of
the new technology that's coming
online.
Is decarbonization an
opportunity or challenge
for South work?
Decarbonization is a huge
opportunity for South Wire.
If you think about everything that's
put in in terms of carbon
that's being emitted.
Going to an electric platform
is much better for the environment.
And we as a manufacturing company
are right in the midst of the sweet
spot for that.
So we're different from other
companies because when you look at
the manufacturing of wire,
most of the carbon that's released
goes through in the end stages,
and we're working upstream and
downstream to try and reduce that
carbon. South wire is actually
the largest user of copper in
the United States.
Larger than the government.
Yes. So we actually
use about 2 billion pounds of
copper a year.
Okay. So there is a truck
that leaves the Port of Florida and
comes to our headquarters in Georgia
and our manufacturing facility every
11 minutes.
Our focus on carbon reduction
is not only to innovate, but it's
to look for ways that as we're
working with our partners, can
we develop new products or
use the products that we have much
more efficient?
The great thing about working with
the partners is we're all like
minded. We are pushing efforts
because we recognize that
if we're going to make a difference,
if we're really going to focus on
making sure that the planet doesn't
increase its temperature by one
and a half degrees, we all
have to come together.
Can we do the necessary actions
to reduce the carbon that's being
emitted at the time?
And that's our focus.
Can you give us some examples of the
success that you're seeing?
We're putting in wires to help
manufacturing companies and other
companies become more efficient.
We're also looking at the downside.
What can we do?
There's a lot of infrastructure
dollars going to ports, whether it's
seaports or airports.
We're helping those institutions
find ways to be more efficient in
the manufacturing and how they
deliver the end product, which
ultimately goes to the consumer.
How does that affect profits?
We have seen a lot of
demand for our products, which has
made it very profitable for us,
but we continue to deploy those
profits into ways to say, can
we become more efficient?
Can we create new innovation in
electrical wire, and what else can
we do to help improve society?
And that's a focus of our
shareholders, where small group
of shareholders family owned
business. But they're very focused
on the future.
And as they like to say, they're
thinking about ownership
for the next 100 years.
So that means that they have to have
a very long view on what can be done
to reduce carbon, to save the
planet, and to be a good corporate
citizen.
